embeds.title: Called Shot
embeds.description:
Common Attack / 0 :energy_hermit:  / The Hermit / Downfall

 (**Retain**.)
Deal 5 (7) damage.
If the last card played this turn triggered Dead On, draw a card.

messages.content: weird card
I love this card's design and Its one of the best damage commons, It scales well with most ways Hermit scales damage and Its a 0 cost for LotD
It being 0 cost also makes It easier to trigger Dead On on other cards
The upgrade is pretty good though usually I have higher priority upgrades, makes Vantage more valuable
Works well with more Dead On in the deck and Take Aim so you can get the draw consistently
Its not even bad If you dont get to draw, since 0 cost for 5 damage is pretty good with bruise, strength, Roulette and Luck of the draw
Basically can't go wrong taking this
I don't remember what it used to do but I think the old version was good too
But I say that as someone who literally always plays hermit for the dead on package
It used to draw attacks I think
Here is it and enervate
Which fun fact: is an infinite
and before that it used to deal damage based on cards in hand and drew a card when dead-on

A damage card I like quite a bit to help with act 1 and 2. When you only have 3 energy, it helps a lot with getting extra output, and can lead to some significant burst when paired with other attacks and memento’s vulnerable. This card also works nicely with dead-on in two ways, though it can’t typically do both at the same time. Either you play this before your dead-on cards to cheaply move your hand around, or you play it after to draw an extra card. Pairs well with bruise cards too, since this can always follow them up for 0 energy and capitalize on the bonus damage. Great enabler for the ninja relics if you happen to find them as well. I don’t tend to find that I need to put in much work to make this a card I am happy to have, and it has lots of room to get better if you do find the right supporting synergies. Even if you miss the draw bonus, you are still getting pretty reasonable damage compared to slice and anger.

The upgrade is very interesting, letting you hold onto it to try and get that bonus draw more often. It also has the subtle synergy of blocking off the leftmost part of your hand, which is the worst place a dead-on card can be, enabling itself more frequently in that way too. It's a really cool upgrade, but I don't take it very often. In many short hallway and elite fights, you just need the damage as soon as possible, and you often can't afford to retain it.  You also usually want to get higher damage from your upgrades in the early game and the +2 is very poor when compared to some of hermits better upgrades (+6 on high caliber, +4 on headshot, +4 on misfire, +4 on pistol whip if you play even one attack after it). I also put a very high priority on runic pyramid for hermit, which clashes with this upgrade.
Its pretty good in any build imo, curse build draws mainly using LotD and Roulette, which both love low cost stuff, though Called Shot is certainly better with Dead On
lmao <spite> literally is the curse draw one and isn't even mentioned

embeds.title: Spite
embeds.description:
Uncommon Attack / 1 :energy_hermit:  / The Hermit / Downfall

Deal 7 (10) damage.
Draw a card for each **Curse** in your hand.

messages.content: Spite should be draw for each curse +1

ever since this card got changed I've never found myself wanting to add it into a deck. its like a flash of steel but you have to have dead on that turn or its worthless (hermit does not need a 0 cost 5 damage card ever). It doesn't end up being very good even in decks that can get dead on every turn because this card is bad in acts 3 and 4. with hermit having crippling "I die to a20 heart syndrome" making your deck worse in that fight is really bad. It works with luck of the draw but thats really it as far as good synergies work and it has several anti synergies  that ruin the card most of the time (bad hit off gambit, cheat and eternal forms)

I don't see anything wrong with spite, it draws you at least 2 cards in the decks you want to take it in which is pretty decent. If the fight drags on and your deck gets really clunked up it draws even more cards and helps you stay on top. It does its job and I respect the card for that.
Spite is so fucking slow in a type of deck that already has trouble with slowness, spite only becomes good the 2nd time through the deck when you already loaded It up with curses
Curse decks really dont like a brick the First time through, they need help setting up quickly
with fatal desire upgraded you will have at least 2 curses in your hand each turn if you don't play your memento
plus how many other curses you are getting from the other cards
With Fatal Desire you already have enough draw and Roulette becomes amazing
Hermit can also do much better than 1 energy draw 2
more card draw is still good for a deck thats shuffling a ton of unplayable cards
Also, fatal Desire decks run into hand space issues, making Roulette more ideal
Ive never felt like spite was a good pick, Hermit has a Lot of better card draw options
Spite is takeable in a curse deck if no other non-dead On card draw options show up
0 cost 5 damage is pretty good on Hermit, Its a good payoff for strength and bruise, Its exactly the type of damage common that is okay to have against the Heart
Pays off of scaling and draws cards sometimes
Its not even bad with Eternal form, as Eternal Form really likes card draw and makes It easy to trigger Dead on
so does snap shot, your main card you want to see as often as possible in that fight
damage isnt a big concern for dead on based stuff anyways because with cards like head shot your able to do enough damage to win in 6-8 turns, its just surviving thats your concern
Yup, since Called Shot sometimes draws a card It makes you draw Snapshot again faster
its not card positive though, you still lose your draw and have to take 2 damage (and use dead on) to get your card back
Its a good pick for a damage common early game because It clogs your deck less late game
I don't take flash of steel on hermit for the same reasons, although that card is much rarer then this one so maybe I just have a bad sample size
its probably at its best in act 1. I just don't think hermit needs so much help in act 1 since he has good damage cards and i'm more concerned about the end game when playing him.
It has massive hand clog issues, it does literally nothing the first deck cycle, it's really low damage, and it's not even great draw.
With fatal desire you don't need spite.
I agree, thats why I usually prefer Called Shot over Head Shot in Dead on decks, usually damage isnt that much of an issue
Also spite has to deal with luck of the draw, which is another uncommon draw card that naturally synergizes with curses.
The low energy cost and draw makes me able to play defense and draw more effectively
luck of the draw is a lot better but you won't always have one and theres still a place for additional card draw (it also does a bit of damage)
7(10) damage for 1 cost is literally 1 more than a strike. The draw only works when you don't need it as much, and works best when you hand is full of curses, but then your hand hits 10 cards.
Spite is just really janky, plus it has literally nothing going for it outside of curse decks.
It is probably a bottom 5 hermit card, down there with high noon and showdown

These are probably the only 2 cards worse than it.

@SamLL That's fair. In my experience, hermit really needs to line up the right cards with the right turns, especially against the heart, where the difference between playing gestalt on an X15 turn and a big hit is night and day, roundhouse kick can buy you a free turn, and getting flash powder applied after the hearts first buff is critical. Hermit has very few tools that allow them to get the right card played on the right turn, and so pyramid is premium. It even gives you a second chance to get your cards dead-on if you can afford to wait a turn.

You are correct that nearly every class values pyramid highly, the ability to line the right card up for the right turn is incredibly value for everyone. I have experienced what Evab is talking about with guardian and heavy stasis builds, and I would also say that some classes put a very high priority on snecko eye (snecko, ironclad, defect, collector) which mixes very poorly with pyramid, though of course both are excellent relics that can be the backbone of a run if you build around them effectively. For what it's worth, I think that hermit is one of the worst snecko eye characters, since it completely shuts off eternal form, makes landing dead-on very difficult, and hermit lacks some of the really expensive, high impact cards of other classes.

Good point, pyramid is _even better_ for hermit. Just chuckling because I think of the pyramid as in strong contention for #1 boss relic on every class. (And agreed, of course that if you already took Act 1 Snecko Eye then Act 2 Pyramid is not nearly as compelling. )
Obviously in the unreasonable and degenerate way I play Guardian the pyramid is fantastic, by the way
I almost never take pyramid but maybe I'm just playing wrong. Doesn't it just end up with your basic cards clogging up your hand?

I disliked it at first for that reason, thinking of the worst possible scenario, but on average it is 'drawing' 3-4 cards per turn and also making sure that your most specific cards can be used on the best possible turns (eg Piercing Wail vs multiattacks). I was convinced to reevaluate by watching Baalorlord on YouTube.

@Brickman If you're almost never taking pyramid, you could improve your win rate by doing so. It allows you to line the right cards up with the right turn, which is enormously powerful. If you've ever been attacked for 30+ damage on a turn where you drew no block, or drawn an AOE card on the turn that gremlin leader is summoning, or drawn your piercing wail on the turn that book of stabbing does the single hit, those are all spots where pyramid excels. Pyramid is a one relic solution to the nemesis elite in act 3, allowing you to always have block when you need, and save your damage for the turns where it isn't intangible.

Beyond that, it's also extremely strong with combos and synergy pieces. You can guarantee that you will line reflex/tactician up with a discard outlet, you know that you can line double tap or burst up with your best attacks/skills. You can guarantee that flex and limit break+ are played together, or that you can hold onto your talk to the hand until after you've cleared the enemies artifact with wave of the hand. It allows you to play some niche cards like concentrate, amplify, flechettes, or X You can proc art of war effortlessly, saving your attacks for the next turn and still getting value from them. You can wait until you have 3 attacks to play to guarantee proccing your kunai/shuriken. It allows you to use finisher in tandem with several cheap attacks or blade dance for massive damage very consistently. You can hold catalyst to use it at the best possible moment. You can hold onto your biggest attack or a source of vulnerable to maximize the damage from pen nib. You can also use runic pyramid with infinites to make sure that you are holding most of your deck in your hand. Also very powerful with fatal cards like feed or ritual dagger, and to let you hold onto reaper so that you can play it near the end of the fight after gaining a bunch of strength and heal back to full.
from beyond is a powerful form of damage scaling but it isn't the best card ever

Certainly you want to try and prioritize card removal higher so that you're not getting clogged up with strikes and defends, and you are much more interested in taking 0 cost cards and energy generating card so that you can free your hand more easily. Anything that lets you exhaust cards like true grit goes up since they let you remove curses, statuses, and basics. But even without that stuff, you can still average 3/4 cards played per turn most of the time, which means you won't get clogged that fast if you are drawing 5 cards a turn
